Abstract

The width Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T of the deconfinement transition region is shown to influence strongly the flow structure in the (Landau–) hydrodynamical expansion of a quark–gluon plasma. For a sharp first order transition (Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0) the mixed phase is rather long-lived, with a lifetime that has a maximum when the initial energy density is at the phase boundary between mixed and pure quark–gluon matter. For increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, however, the lifetime decreases rapidly. Hadronic matter, however, remains long-lived as a consequence of the rapid change in the degrees of freedom in the transition region and the corresponding “softening” of the equation of state.

Columbia preprint CU–TP–706

1 Introduction

The hydrodynamical approach has been applied extensively to describe the dynamics of relativistic heavy–ion collisions [1, 2, 3], because it provides the only direct link between the equation of state of hot and dense nuclear matter and observable collective flow phenomena. Hydrodynamics is defined by local energy–momentum and (net) charge conservation,

The system of m+4𝑚4italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:4m+4 equations (1) is closed via eliminating one of the m+5𝑚5italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:5m+5 unknowns in eqs. (2) by choosing an equation of state e.g. in the form p=p⁢(ϵ,n1,…,nm)𝑝𝑝italic-ϵsubscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑚italic-p RELOP:equals italic-p OPEN:( italic-epsilon PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)p=p(\epsilon,n_{1},...,n_{m}). In the ideal fluid approximation, the (equilibrium) equation of state is the only input to the hydrodynamical equations of motion (1) that relates to properties of the matter under consideration and is thus able to influence the dynamical evolution of the system. The final results are uniquely determined once a particular initial condition and a decoupling (“freeze–out”) hypersurface are specified.

In ultrarelativistic heavy–ion collisions (s∼200similar-to𝑠200italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:200\sqrt{s}\sim 200 AGeV), the central region (in the center-of-momentum frame) is essentially free of (net) charges, due to the insufficient amount of baryon stopping [5], and the charge conservation equations in (1) do not have to be solved explicitly to describe the fluid evolution in this particular region of space–time. Moreover, the equation of state depends only on a single independent thermodynamical variable, for instance the temperature T𝑇italic-TT. From the pressure as a function of T𝑇italic-TT, p⁢(T)𝑝𝑇italic-p OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)p(T), one derives the entropy density s≡d⁢p/d⁢T𝑠d𝑝d𝑇italic-s RELOP:equivalent-to d italic-p MULOP:divide d italic-Ts\equiv{\rm d}p/{\rm d}T, and the energy density ϵ≡T⁢s-pitalic-ϵ𝑇𝑠𝑝italic-epsilon RELOP:equivalent-to italic-T italic-s ADDOP:minus italic-p\epsilon\equiv Ts-p.

For this particular case, lattice QCD calculations [6] provide fundamental information on the equation of state of strongly interacting matter. These calculations [7] show a rapid increase of the entropy density as a function of temperature, s⁢(T)𝑠𝑇italic-s OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)s(T), in a narrow temperature interval Δ⁢T∼10similar-toΔ𝑇10Delta italic-T RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\Delta T\sim 10 MeV around a temperature Tc≃150similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑇𝑐150italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:150T_{c}\simeq 150 MeV, indicating the presence of a transition from hadronic degrees of freedom at low temperatures to quark and gluon degrees of freedom at high temperatures. For a first order phase transition, the increase in s𝑠italic-ss is actually a discontinuity, and Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T is zero, while for a second or higher order transition the change of the entropy density is continuous, and Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T is finite. Thusfar, however, lattice calculations have not converged on the order of the QCD phase transition [8, 9, 10], and we only know that Δ⁢T≤0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T\leq 0.1\,T_{c}.

In this paper we discuss the sensitivity of the structure of hydrodynamic flow to this uncertainty in the equation of state. To this end we treat the width Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T of the transition region as a free parameter and assume the following functional form for the entropy density [11],

s⁢(T)=cH⁢T3⁢1-tanh⁡[(T-Tc)/Δ⁢T]2+cQ⁢T3⁢1+tanh⁡[(T-Tc)/Δ⁢T]2.𝑠𝑇subscript𝑐𝐻superscript𝑇31𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐Δ𝑇2subscript𝑐𝑄superscript𝑇31𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐Δ𝑇2italic-s OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus TRIGFUNCTION:hyperbolic-tangent OPEN:[ OPEN:( italic-T ADDOP:minus italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide Delta italic-T CLOSE:] ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus TRIGFUNCTION:hyperbolic-tangent OPEN:[ OPEN:( italic-T ADDOP:minus italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide Delta italic-T CLOSE:] ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PERIOD:.s(T)=c_{H}\,T^{3}\,\frac{1-\tanh[(T-T_{c})/\Delta T]}{2}+c_{Q}\,T^{3}\,\frac{1% +\tanh[(T-T_{c})/\Delta T]}{2}~{}. (3)

Other functional forms are, of course, also possible and eq. (3) is chosen only for the sake of simplicity. We denote the ratio of degrees of freedom in the quark–gluon and hadron phases by r≡cQ/cH𝑟subscript𝑐𝑄subscript𝑐𝐻italic-r RELOP:equivalent-to italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr\equiv c_{Q}/c_{H}. If the hadron phase is taken to be an ideal, massless pion gas, and the quark–gluon plasma to consist of (non-interacting, massless) u𝑢italic-uu and d𝑑italic-dd quarks and gluons, then r=37/3𝑟373italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:37 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3r=37/3. In the limit Δ⁢T→0→Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:0\Delta T\rightarrow 0 the equation of state (3) features a first order phase transition between the two phases at the phase transition temperature Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} and reduces to the MIT bag model equation of state [12]. In this paper we vary Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T between 00NUMBER:0 and 0.1⁢Tc0.1subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.1\,T_{c}, consistent with the uncertainties in present lattice QCD data.

The first study of the sensitivity of hydrodynamic flow on Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T was done in [11]. It was found that for Δ⁢T<Δ⁢T*Δ𝑇Δsuperscript𝑇Delta italic-T RELOP:less-than Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T<\Delta T^{*}, where Δ⁢T*≃0.07⁢Tcsimilar-to-or-equalsΔsuperscript𝑇0.07subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.07 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T^{*}\simeq 0.07\,T_{c}, matter is thermodynamically anomalous in the phase transition region and, consequently, that rarefaction shock waves occur in the one–dimensional expansion [13, 14]. On the other hand, for Δ⁢T≥Δ⁢T*Δ𝑇Δsuperscript𝑇Delta italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T\geq\Delta T^{*}, matter is thermodynamically normal everywhere and simple rarefaction waves form the hydrodynamically stable solution. The main result of Ref. [11], however, was that, for the particular initial conditions chosen in that work, those structural differences had little effect on the final flow pattern. This led the authors of [11] to the conclusion that observables, such as the distribution of outgoing particles, would hardly be affected by the uncertainty in Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T.

Renewed interest in the sensitivity of hydrodynamic flow on the equation of state has arisen as a consequence of the work of Refs. [14, 15, 16]. It was demonstrated that a phase transition leads to a so-called [15] “softest point” in the equation of state, defined by a minimum in the ratio p/ϵ𝑝italic-ϵitalic-p MULOP:divide italic-epsilonp/\epsilon. For the equation of state (3) with Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, this point occurs at the phase boundary between mixed and pure quark–gluon matter (see also Section 2). It was argued [15] that at this point the comparatively small pressure prevents a fast expansion and cooling of the system. This leads to a maximum in the lifetime of mixed phase matter as a function of the initial energy density. On this basis it was suggested [15] that the resulting enhanced emission of electromagnetic probes from this long-lived mixed phase could serve as a signature for the creation of the quark–gluon plasma in ultrarelativistic heavy–ion collisions.

In Ref. [16], the suppressed tendency for expansion at the softest point was shown to cause a minimum in the excitation function of the directed transverse collective flow in semi-peripheral collisions. It was proposed that this minimum would also be a unique signature for the phase transition. Another important observable sensitive to the lifetime of the plasma is pion interferometry [17]. In the standard “slowly burning log” scenario inspired by the small deflagration velocities associated with sharp transitions [18] one expects a dramatic difference between “out”– and “side”–correlations, which could serve as a signal of the phase transition.

In the present work, we investigate the hydrodynamic flow pattern for one–dimensional expansion in greater detail than in [11]. In particular, we focus on the question of the lifetime of different parts of the system as a function of the initial energy density ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} and the width Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T of the transition region. While one–dimensional hydrodynamics is not realistic for a detailed comparison with heavy–ion data, its simplicity allows us to study the influence of the equation of state on the hydrodynamic flow without additional effects originating from more complicated geometries.

We confirm the observation made in [11] that, for initial energy densities well above or below the softest point of the equation of state, the temperature profiles in the thermodynamically normal case (Δ⁢T≥Δ⁢T*Δ𝑇Δsuperscript𝑇Delta italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T\geq\Delta T^{*}) look indeed similar to those in the thermodynamically anomalous case (Δ⁢T<Δ⁢T*Δ𝑇Δsuperscript𝑇Delta italic-T RELOP:less-than Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T<\Delta T^{*}). However, we demonstrate that the temperature profiles are quite sensitive to a variation of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T for ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} near the softest point of the equation of state. In particular, the lifetime of matter with temperatures near Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} decreases rapidly for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. On the other hand, the lifetime of matter with temperatures well below Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} remains large and may even grow for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. This is due to the “softening” of the equation of state by the change of degrees of freedom across the transition region. Thus, the detectability of the quark–gluon plasma via enhanced emission of electromagnetic probes may depend sensitively on Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, while other observables such as flow and correlation functions are expected to remain fairly insensitive to that uncertainty.

This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we review properties of the equation of state (3) in greater detail and establish the connection to thermodynamically normal or anomalous behaviour. Section 3 presents the expansion solutions as functions of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} and Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. In Section 4 we discuss the lifetimes of parts of the system having different temperatures. Section 5 concludes this work with a summary of our results.

2 Equation of state and thermodynamical behaviour

In this section we discuss the equation of state (3) and its thermodynamical properties. The square of the velocity of sound is

In Fig. 1 we show the energy density, the pressure, the entropy density, and the square of the velocity of sound as functions of temperature. Note that above Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c}, the energy density approaches the Stefan–Boltzmann value for a quark–gluon gas from above, while the pressure approaches it rather slowly from below. Both phenomena are observed in lattice data [7], and are a consequence of general thermodynamical relationships [19].

A way to classify the structure of one–dimensional hydrodynamical solutions [13, 14] is through the sign of

(8)

Matter is called thermodynamically normal if ΣΣSigma\Sigma is positive and thermodynamically anomalous if it is negative. It was shown in [11, 13, 14] that in the first case the hydrodynamically stable solution for the one–dimensional expansion of semi-infinite matter is a simple rarefaction wave, while in the latter case it is a rarefaction shock wave. Depending on the value of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, the equation of state (3) features thermodynamically normal as well as thermodynamically anomalous regions, as discussed below. The hydrodynamical solution for the one–dimensional expansion of semi-infinite matter may thus consist of a sequence of simple waves and shocks. For the one–dimensional expansion of finite matter, the expansion solution is that for semi-infinite matter as long as the rarefaction waves have not reached the center of symmetry of the system (usually taken to be the center of the coordinate system, x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0). Afterwards, the solution no longer consists only of simple waves and shocks but is more complicated (see also next section). An analytic solution is so far only known for thermodynamically normal matter with a constant velocity of sound [20].

To see where matter described by (3) becomes thermodynamically anomalous, it is advantageous to plot thermodynamic quantities as a function of the energy density, since in the case Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, the mapping T→ϵ⁢(T)→𝑇italic-ϵ𝑇italic-T ARROW:rightarrow italic-epsilon OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)T\rightarrow\epsilon(T) is not one-to-one. Moreover, the beam energy fixes the initial energy density, while the initial temperature is determined only indirectly through the equation of state. First, the fact that tanh⁡Θ⁢(TΣ)Θsubscript𝑇ΣTRIGFUNCTION:hyperbolic-tangent Theta OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\tanh\Theta(T_{\Sigma}) is not small leads to a large shift of ϵΣsubscriptitalic-ϵΣitalic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{\Sigma} away from the point ϵcsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑐italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{c} already to zeroth order in Δ⁢T/TcΔ𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T MULOP:divide italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T/T_{c} . In this sense, the case Δ⁢T≡0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:0\Delta T\equiv 0 is very special in that it features an exceptionally large region where matter is thermodynamically anomalous.

3 One–dimensional expansion solutions

In this section the one–dimensional hydrodynamic expansion of a finite slab of matter with (homogeneously distributed) initial energy density ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} is investigated with emphasis on the dependence of the flow structure on ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} and Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. To solve the hydrodynamic equations (1) in (1+1)–dimensions we employ the relativistic Harten–Lax–van Leer–Einfeldt (HLLE) algorithm presented in [14, 22] with a grid spacing of Δ⁢x=0.025⁢RΔ𝑥0.025𝑅Delta italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.025 italic-R\Delta x=0.025\,R (2⁢R2𝑅NUMBER:2 italic-R2\,R being the initial size of the slab) and a time step width of Δ⁢t=0.99⁢Δ⁢xΔ𝑡0.99Δ𝑥Delta italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.99 Delta italic-x\Delta t=0.99\,\Delta x. This algorithm was shown [14] to accurately reproduce hydrodynamic flow profiles for analytically solvable test problems where the equation of state has thermodynamically normal as well as anomalous regions. In particular, for the choice Δ⁢x=0.025⁢RΔ𝑥0.025𝑅Delta italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.025 italic-R\Delta x=0.025\,R, the algorithm accurately reproduced the expansion solution for a finite system of size 2⁢R2𝑅NUMBER:2 italic-R2\,R consisting of thermodynamically normal matter with a constant velocity of sound. (This solution was first provided by Landau in purely analytical form [20], but can also be easily constructed semi-analytically via the method of characteristics [23].)

In the following Figs. 3 – 7 we demonstrate how the flow structure changes systematically in the range ϵH≤ϵ0≤10⁢ϵQsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐻subscriptitalic-ϵ010subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:10 italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{H}\leq\epsilon_{0}\leq 10\,\epsilon_{Q} and for various Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. Each figure corresponds to a fixed ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}, and shows the time evolution of temperature, center-of-momentum frame (CM) energy density, and the space–time structure of isotherms333For Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 all states of mixed phase matter have the same temperature Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c}, cf. Fig. 1 (a). In this case, we define the (T=Tc)𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=T_{c})–isotherm as the set of space–time points where T𝑇italic-TT has just infinitesimally dropped below Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} [14]. in three columns corresponding to Δ⁢T=0, 0.01⁢Tc,Δ𝑇0 0.01subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,\Delta T=0,\,0.01\,T_{c}, and 0.1⁢Tc0.1subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.1\,T_{c}.

3.1 ϵ0=ϵHsubscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐻italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}=\epsilon_{H}

In Fig. 3 we show the expansion solution for an initial energy density ϵ0≡ϵH=3⁢Tc⁢sc/2⁢(r+1)=0.1125⁢Tc⁢scsubscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐻3subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐2𝑟10.1125subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1125 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}\equiv\epsilon_{H}=3\,T_{c}\,s_{c}/2(r+1)=0.1125\,T_{c}\,s_{c}. For Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, Figs. 3 (a,d,g), this energy density corresponds to the boundary between hadronic and mixed phase matter. Thus, thermodynamically anomalous regions of the equation of state are not reached during the expansion, and the expansion proceeds at first as a simple rarefaction wave. After this simple wave overlaps with its symmetric counterpart coming from the (-x)𝑥OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:)(-x)–direction, the hydrodynamical solution is identical to that given by Landau [20].

For Δ⁢T=0.01⁢TcΔ𝑇0.01subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.01\,T_{c}, Figs. 3 (b,e,h), the expansion seems to proceed rather similar to the previous case. Fig. 2 (d) shows, however, that around ϵ0=ϵHsubscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐻italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}=\epsilon_{H} the equation of state has a region where matter is thermodynamically anomalous. Thus, a rarefaction shock wave is bound to form in the expansion. Since the anomalous region is confined to a very narrow range about ϵHsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐻italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{H}, cf. Fig. 2 (d), the shock is weak and difficult to resolve numerically. The best evidence for its existence can be found in Fig. 3 (e), in that the slope of the rarefaction wave travelling into the slab is steeper than in the corresponding Figs. 3 (d,f) where no shock occurs.

For Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, Figs. 3 (c,f,i), matter is thermodynamically normal everywhere, cf. Fig. 2 (d). Consequently, the expansion initially proceeds as a simple rarefaction wave, as for Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0. For such a wave, the matter velocity with respect to the wave profile equals the velocity of sound [4, 14]. Thus, the head of the simple wave travels with the velocity of sound cssubscript𝑐𝑠italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endc_{s} into matter which is initially at rest. In the respective range of energy densities, cssubscript𝑐𝑠italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endc_{s} is considerably smaller for Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c} than for Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, cf. Fig. 2 (c). Therefore, as can be clearly seen in Figs. 3 (c,f), it takes much longer for the simple rarefaction wave to reach the center x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 than in Figs. 3 (a,d). The delayed rarefaction can be also seen comparing Figs. 3 (g) and (i): it takes about 4⁢R4𝑅NUMBER:4 italic-R4\,R for the system at x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 to cool below T=0.7⁢Tc𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.7\,T_{c} and about 6⁢R6𝑅NUMBER:6 italic-R6\,R to cool below T=0.5⁢Tc𝑇0.5subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.5\,T_{c}, while the corresponding values for Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 are 3⁢R3𝑅NUMBER:3 italic-R3\,R and 5⁢R5𝑅NUMBER:5 italic-R5\,R.

The reason why there is no (T=Tc)𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=T_{c})–isotherm in Fig. 3 (h) and no (T=Tc)𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=T_{c})– and (T=0.9⁢Tc)𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=0.9\,T_{c})–isotherm in Fig. 3 (i) can be inferred from Fig. 1 (a): as long as the energy density is below ϵc≡(2⁢r+1)⁢Tc⁢sc/2⁢(r+1)=0.9625⁢Tc⁢scsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑐2𝑟1subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐2𝑟10.9625subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-r ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9625 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{c}\equiv(2r+1)\,T_{c}\,s_{c}/2(r+1)=0.9625\,T_{c}\,s_{c}, the temperature corresponding to that energy density is smaller for larger Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. Thus, for Δ⁢T=0.01⁢TcΔ𝑇0.01subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.01\,T_{c}, already the initial temperature is below Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c}, and for Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c} even below 0.9⁢Tc0.9subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.9\,T_{c}, cf. Figs. 3 (b,c). Therefore, there simply are no corresponding isotherms in the space–time diagram.

Note that the temperature and CM energy density profiles show a minimum at x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 for late times t𝑡italic-tt. As was explained in [14], this is essentially a relativistic effect. At finite x𝑥italic-xx, matter is moving, while due to symmetry it is at rest at x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0. Moving matter, however, experiences relativistic time dilation and is thus less diluted and still hotter at a given time in the CM frame than matter at rest. Of course, the degree of dilation a fluid element experiences is determined by its velocity. This velocity is, in turn, determined by the “stiffness” of the equation of state, i.e., the ratio of pressure to energy density, since that ratio influences the acceleration of fluid elements. Thus, for the typical energy densities occurring in Fig. 3, matter velocities are smaller for larger values of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, since the equation of state is softer, cf. Fig. 2 (b). This explains why the minimum at x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 (or the time dilation effect, respectively) is less pronounced (and occurs at later times) in Figs. 3 (c,f) than for instance in Figs. 3 (a,d).

Therefore, we expect for ϵ0/ϵH=2⁢(r+1)⁢ϵ0/3⁢Tc⁢sc=10subscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐻2𝑟1subscriptitalic-ϵ03subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐10italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\epsilon_{0}/\epsilon_{H}=2(r+1)\epsilon_{0}/3\,T_{c}\,s_{c}=10 a lifetime tl⁢i⁢f⁢e≡R/|vs⁢h|≃26⁢Rsubscript𝑡𝑙𝑖𝑓𝑒𝑅subscript𝑣𝑠ℎsimilar-to-or-equals26𝑅italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-i italic-f italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-R MULOP:divide VERTBAR:| italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:26 italic-Rt_{life}\equiv R/|v_{sh}|\simeq 26\,R, in accord with Fig. 4 (g).

Again, the expansion for Δ⁢T=0.01⁢TcΔ𝑇0.01subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.01\,T_{c} looks similar, especially the temperature profiles, cf. Figs. 4 (a) and (b). The difference is that now the initial energy density is well above the region where matter is thermodynamically anomalous, cf. Fig. 2 (d). Therefore, the expansion has at first to proceed as a simple rarefaction wave, until the energy density has dropped sufficiently to reach that region. Then, a rarefaction shock wave provides further dilution. This can be most clearly seen in the CM energy density profiles, Fig. 4 (e). The reason why the temperature profiles, Fig. 4 (b), do not clearly exhibit this behaviour is that T𝑇italic-TT is proportional to a fractional power of ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon, so that the range of high energy densities is not well resolved when plotted as a function of temperature. A clear indication for this behaviour, however, can be found comparing the space–time diagram Fig. 4 (g), where the (T=0.9⁢Tc)𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=0.9\,T_{c})– and (T=Tc)𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=T_{c})–isotherms coincide, since both temperatures occur at the position of the shock, with Fig. 4 (h), where they are well separated due to the simple rarefaction wave preceding the shock. Note that this has a drastic influence on the lifetime of matter with T=Tc𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{c}. Such matter is thermodynamically normal for finite Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, as discussed in the context of Fig. 2 (d), and consequently rapidly diluted by the simple rarefaction wave. The lifetime drops by more than a factor of 2 as compared to Fig. 4 (g). On the other hand, the lifetime of matter with T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} remains comparable to that in the case Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, since this temperature occurs on the rarefaction shock front, cf. Fig. 4 (b), as was also the case in Fig. 4 (a). We will discuss this phenomenon in more detail in the next section.

For Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, Figs. 4 (c,f,i), matter is thermodynamically normal everywhere and the hydrodynamically stable rarefaction solution is a simple wave (until it reaches the center x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 and overlaps with its counterpart from the (-x)𝑥OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:)(-x)–region). Nevertheless, due to the variation of the velocity of sound in the phase transition region, cf. Fig. 2 (c), the shape of the simple wave exhibits a “bump” faintly resembling a smeared version of the rarefaction shock occurring in the previous two cases. This bump, however, is moving rapidly in positive x𝑥italic-xx–direction, in contrast to the rarefaction shock in Fig. 4 (b), which is approximately stationary, or that in Fig. 4 (a), which is even slowly moving in (-x)𝑥OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:)(-x)–direction. This has the effect that the hot parts of the system (T≥0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT\geq 0.9\,T_{c}) cool faster than in the two previous cases. This can be understood with the help of Fig. 2 (b) which shows that for the respective energy densities the equation of state is “stiffer” for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, thus increasing the system’s tendency to expand and cool.

On the other hand, the cooler parts (T≤0.7⁢Tc𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT\leq 0.7\,T_{c}) keep their temperature longer for Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, cf. also Figs. 4 (g,h,i). The reason is that the equation of state for small energy densities (low temperatures) is softer than in the other two cases, cf. Fig. 2 (b). Thus, the acceleration and consequently the matter velocities are smaller, and therefore the rarefaction and cooling take longer. We finally mention that, since now ϵ0>ϵcsubscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑐italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}>\epsilon_{c}, the initial temperature increases with Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, cf. Fig. 1 (a), in contrast to the previous case, Fig. 3.

For Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, Figs. 5 (a,d,g), this energy density is just above the softest point of the equation of state, i.e., the phase boundary between mixed and pure quark–gluon matter, ϵQ≡(4⁢r-1)⁢Tc⁢sc/2⁢(r+1)=1.8125⁢Tc⁢scsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄4𝑟1subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐2𝑟11.8125subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to OPEN:( NUMBER:4 italic-r ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.8125 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{Q}\equiv(4r-1)T_{c}\,s_{c}/2(r+1)=1.8125\,T_{c}\,s_{c}. Consequently, a simple rarefaction wave precedes the rarefaction shock wave travelling into hot quark–gluon matter [14]. (The simple rarefaction wave is not visible in Fig. 5 (a) due to the large time step chosen.) This has the consequence that matter is pre-accelerated before it enters the shock wave. The temperature profiles for Δ⁢T=0.01⁢TcΔ𝑇0.01subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.01\,T_{c}, Fig. 5 (b), look again similar to that of Fig. 5 (a), although the shock wave is no longer stationary, but at first advancing in x𝑥italic-xx–direction. The reason is that the shock strength is smaller than in the previous case (due to the much narrower region where matter is thermodynamically anomalous, cf. Fig. 2 (d)), which is especially obvious from comparing Figs. 5 (d) and (e). Therefore, the velocity of the shock, which is originally directed inwards, is too small to compete with the pre-acceleration of matter in the simple rarefaction wave preceding the shock, resulting in a net outward motion of the shock. This mechanism is also responsible for the positive shock velocity observed for higher ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} in the cases Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 and 0.01⁢Tc0.01subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.01\,T_{c}, see Figs. 6, 7 below. For later times, however, just before the high energy density matter in the center is completely consumed, the shock reverses its direction, due to the fact that the energy density (or pressure) in the interior has now become too small to keep it driving outwards. (This effect is also visible in Fig. 5 (a).)

The energy density profiles, Fig. 5 (e), do not show the minimum at x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 typical for relativistic time dilation of moving matter. The reason is that in this case the equation of state is soft for the respective energy densities, cf. Fig. 2 (b). As explained above, this leads to small (i.e. non-relativistic) matter velocities and the absence of an appreciable amount of time dilation.

The expansion for Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, Fig. 5 (c,f) resembles the corresponding one in Figs. 4 (c,f). In particular, the “bump” structure caused by the variation of the velocity of sound is again clearly visible. As in Fig. 4, however, the expansion differs appreciably from the one for Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 and 0.01⁢Tc0.01subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.01\,T_{c} in Figs. 5 (a,b,d,e).

The relative time scales of cooling are similar to the previous case ϵ0=1.125⁢Tc⁢scsubscriptitalic-ϵ01.125subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.125 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}=1.125\,T_{c}\,s_{c}, cf. Figs. 4 (g,h,i) with Figs. 5 (g,h,i). Note again the sharp decrease in the lifetime of matter with T=Tc𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{c} for Δ⁢T=0.01⁢TcΔ𝑇0.01subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.01\,T_{c} as compared to the case Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, while matter with T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} remains long-lived. For Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, also the lifetime of matter with temperature T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} is reduced, while matter that is even cooler still lives longer.

3.4 ϵ0∼2⁢ϵQsimilar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ02subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2 italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}\sim 2\,\epsilon_{Q}

Fig. 6 shows the expansion for an initial energy density ϵ0=100⁢Tc⁢sc/2⁢(r+1)=3.75⁢Tc⁢sc∼2⁢ϵQsubscriptitalic-ϵ0100subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐2𝑟13.75subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐similar-to2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:100 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.75 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2 italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}=100\,T_{c}\,s_{c}/2(r+1)=3.75\,T_{c}\,s_{c}\sim 2\,\epsilon_{Q}. This case is of interest since for initial energy densities of this order of magnitude a rather peculiar phenomenon occurs in the expansion for an equation of state with Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0. One observes in Figs. 6 (a,d) that the rarefaction shock wave is now driven outwards by the pre-acceleration from the simple rarefaction wave, as was already discussed above. Matter behind the shock experiences cooling typical for the Landau expansion with a sufficiently stiff equation of state, i.e., slower matter near the center x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 cools more rapidly than faster matter at larger x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0. This, however, has the consequence that as soon as the (comoving) energy density drops below ϵHsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐻italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{H}, or equivalently, the temperature drops below Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c}, a second rarefaction shock wave develops that connects hadronic matter in the center with mixed phase matter behind the first shock.

The occurrence of the second shock could have been expected, since matter changes from thermodynamically anomalous in the mixed phase to thermodynamically normal in the hadron phase. To our knowledge there is now, however, no general mathematical theorem rigorously proving the existence of this second shock, as was the case in the expansion of semi-infinite matter studied in [14]. The shock has an interesting further consequence: just as the first shock expells hadronic matter outwards, the second accelerates matter inwards. Therefore, there is an accumulation of matter in the center which is consequently reheated instead of cooled. This reheating of the center can be clearly seen in Fig. 6 (g), where the triangle-shaped isotherm at small x𝑥italic-xx and t∼70⁢Rsimilar-to𝑡70𝑅italic-t RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:70 italic-Rt\sim 70\,R is a re-occurrence of the (T=0.9⁢Tc)𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=0.9\,T_{c})–isotherm caused by reheating. In addition, also the (T=0.7⁢Tc)𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=0.7\,T_{c})–isotherm shows that the central region remains hot over a much longer period of time than for the expansion of matter without a phase transition.

The reheating is considerably smaller for Δ⁢T=0.01⁢TcΔ𝑇0.01subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.01\,T_{c}, cf. Figs. 6 (b,e,h), and basically only discernible from the shape of the (T=0.7⁢Tc)𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=0.7\,T_{c})–isotherm. The reason is, of course, that the region in the equation of state, where matter is thermodynamically anomalous, is much narrower, cf. Fig. 2 (d), so that the strength of the second rarefaction shock is smaller and consequently the acceleration of matter towards the center much weaker. For Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c} there is no such an effect at all, and the fluid evolution is rather different from the cases Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 and 0.01⁢Tc0.01subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.01\,T_{c}.

3.5 ϵ0≫ϵQmuch-greater-thansubscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-greater-than italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}\gg\epsilon_{Q}

Finally, we show in Fig. 7 the expansion for ϵ0=500⁢Tc⁢sc/2⁢(r+1)=18.75⁢Tc⁢sc≫ϵQsubscriptitalic-ϵ0500subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐2𝑟118.75subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐much-greater-thansubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:18.75 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-greater-than italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}=500\,T_{c}\,s_{c}/2(r+1)=18.75\,T_{c}\,s_{c}\gg\epsilon_{Q}. This case is similar to the one studied in Fig. 13 in Ref. [11], although we followed the fluid evolution over a much longer time. Here, the acceleration from the simple wave travelling into the quark–gluon phase is rather large, leading to a shock wave in Figs. 7 (a,b,d,e) that is rapidly moving outwards. Note that now also the temperature profiles for Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, Fig. 7 (c), resemble those in the case Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, Fig. 7 (a) (with the exception of the immediate vicinity of the rarefaction shock). The main reason is that the fluid motion is now dominated by the conversion of the large initial energy density into collective motion, so that the influence of the phase transition region on the structure of the hydrodynamic solution becomes less important. Moreover, as in the cases considered previously, the variation of the velocity of sound in the phase transition region causes a “bump” structure that resembles a smeared shock.

The similarity of the temperature profiles in Figs. 7 (a) and (c) led the authors of [11] to the conclusion that final state observables will not be much influenced by the precise value of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. They reached the same conclusion studying the expansion with an initial entropy density s0=0.3⁢scsubscript𝑠00.3subscript𝑠𝑐italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.3 italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{0}=0.3\,s_{c} (Fig. 11 in [11]) which corresponds, for Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, to an initial energy density ϵ0=0.2625⁢Tc⁢scsubscriptitalic-ϵ00.2625subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2625 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}=0.2625\,T_{c}\,s_{c}. For this case, the expansion is similar to the one studied here in Fig. 3. That figure shows that the influence of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T on the expansion is negligible also for such small initial energy densities, confirming the conclusions of [11]. As we have seen, however, the profiles are rather sensitive to the choice of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T for initial energy densities near the softest point of the equation of state. In particular, the reheating phenomenon of Figs. 6 (a,d,g) does not occur at all for Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, cf. Figs. 6 (c,f,i). We discuss the effect on the lifetime of matter with different temperatures in the next section.

4 Lifetime of parts of the system having different temperatures

In this section we discuss the lifetimes of parts of the system having different temperatures. The “lifetime” is defined as the time it takes the system to cool below a certain temperature T*superscript𝑇italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT^{*} at x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0. More precisely, the “lifetime” is the intercept of the isotherm t⁢(x;T*)𝑡𝑥superscript𝑇italic-t OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:; italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)t(x;T^{*}) in the (t-x)𝑡𝑥OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:)(t-x)–plane with the t𝑡italic-tt–axis, i.e., tl⁢i⁢f⁢e≡t⁢(0;T*)subscript𝑡𝑙𝑖𝑓𝑒𝑡0superscript𝑇italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-i italic-f italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-t OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:; italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)t_{life}\equiv t(0;T^{*}). We choose the point x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 to measure this time, since the motion of fluid cells at finite x𝑥italic-xx causes a time dilation which leads to a slower cooling when measured in the global CM frame of the system. In case there is more than one intercept, for instance when there is reheating of the center, Fig. 6 (g), we choose the first.

We investigate the lifetime in two different geometries. In subsection 4.1 we study longitudinal expansion for fixed initial “radius” R𝑅italic-RR of the system. In subsection 4.2 we investigate a more realistic geometry where the initial longitudinal size R𝑅italic-RR takes into account the Lorentz contraction of the colliding nuclei. Thus, R𝑅italic-RR varies with beam energy, and hence with the initial energy density ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}.

4.1 Fixed R𝑅italic-RR

In Fig. 8 we show the lifetime of parts of the system having temperature T=0.5⁢Tc𝑇0.5subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.5\,T_{c}, 0.7⁢Tc, 0.9⁢Tc,Tc, 1.1⁢Tc,0.7subscript𝑇𝑐 0.9subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑇𝑐 1.1subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:1.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,0.7\,T_{c},\,0.9\,T_{c},\,T_{c},\,1.1\,T_{c}, and 1.3⁢Tc1.3subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:1.3 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1.3\,T_{c} for the three different Δ⁢T=0, 0.01⁢Tc, 0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0 0.01subscript𝑇𝑐 0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0,\,0.01\,T_{c},\,0.1\,T_{c}, and for an ideal gas equation of state without phase transition and constant velocity of sound cs=1/3subscript𝑐𝑠13italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:endc_{s}=1/\sqrt{3} as a function of the initial energy density ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}. We measure the lifetime in units of R𝑅italic-RR. For the ideal gas calculation, Fig. 8 (d), there is of course no phase transition, and the temperature scale set by Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} is arbitrary. The results of Fig. 8 (d) were obtained using T0/Tc≡(4⁢ϵ0/3⁢Tc⁢sc)1/4subscript𝑇0subscript𝑇𝑐superscript4subscriptitalic-ϵ03subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐14italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to OPEN:( NUMBER:4 italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT_{0}/T_{c}\equiv(4\,\epsilon_{0}/3\,T_{c}\,s_{c})^{1/4}.

One observes that for initial energy densities smaller than ∼ϵcsimilar-toabsentsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑐RELOP:similar-to italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim\epsilon_{c}, the lifetime of matter with temperatures T≤0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT\leq 0.9\,T_{c} is essentially independent of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. The only exception is that for Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 and 0.01⁢Tc0.01subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.01\,T_{c} the lifetime of matter having T=0.7⁢Tc𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.7\,T_{c} and T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} is equal, while that is not the case for Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}. The reason is obvious from Figs. 4, 5: in the first two cases the rarefaction shock wave, once it reaches the center, abruptly cools matter to about 0.5⁢Tc0.5subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.5 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.5\,T_{c}, thus terminating the existence of matter having T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} as well as T=0.7⁢Tc𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.7\,T_{c} simultaneously. This can be clearly seen in the space–time diagrams Figs. 4, 5 (g) and (h). In the case Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, rarefaction proceeds via simple waves which are continuous solutions and gradually cool the system, and thus matter with T=0.7⁢Tc𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.7\,T_{c} survives longer than hotter matter with T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c}.

The second observation is that the lifetime of “very hot” parts of the system, i.e., matter having temperature T=1.1⁢Tc𝑇1.1subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=1.1\,T_{c} and 1.3⁢Tc1.3subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:1.3 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1.3\,T_{c}, is also comparable for all three values of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. These high temperatures occur, of course, only for sufficiently high initial energy densities. The reason for the similarity in the lifetimes is that a variation of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T has little effect on the equation of state for high energy densities (or temperatures), cf. Fig. 1. Consequently, also the fluid evolution must be similar for these high temperatures .

For initial energy densities near the softest point of the equation of state and for temperatures around Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c}, however, Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T has an appreciable influence on the lifetime. For instance, one clearly observes in Fig. 8 (a) that the lifetime of matter with T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} and T=Tc𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{c} has a maximum near the softest point, cf. Fig. 2 (b). This effect was discussed in detail in Ref. [14] and in the context of Fig. 5 above. It has been explained by the existence of a minimum in the velocity of the rarefaction wave travelling into the system, leading to the “slow burning” of hot matter also observable in Figs. 4, 5 (a,d). An alternative explanation was given in [15], namely that the small p/ϵ𝑝italic-ϵitalic-p MULOP:divide italic-epsilonp/\epsilon–ratio at this point reduces the system’s tendency to expand.

However, Figs. 8 (b,c) show that this maximum in the lifetime is rapidly washed out and eventually vanishes for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, although the p/ϵ𝑝italic-ϵitalic-p MULOP:divide italic-epsilonp/\epsilon–ratio still exhibits a minimum, cf. Fig. 2 (b). This vanishing of the maximum in the lifetime of matter with a particular temperature is essentially explained by a gradual reduction of the lifetime when increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T: first, the lifetime of matter with T=Tc𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{c} is reduced when increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T from 00NUMBER:0 to 0.01⁢Tc0.01subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.01\,T_{c}, cf. Figs. 8 (a) and (b). Then, that of matter with T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} is reduced when further increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T from 0.01⁢Tc0.01subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.01\,T_{c} to 0.1⁢Tc0.1subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.1\,T_{c}, cf. Figs. 8 (b) and (c). The lifetime of cooler matter with T≤0.7⁢Tc𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT\leq 0.7\,T_{c} is not appreciably influenced around ϵ0=ϵQsubscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}=\epsilon_{Q}.

In order to understand this reduction of the lifetime for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, we show in Fig. 9 the time evolution of the temperature at x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 for various values of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T and an initial energy density ϵ=50⁢Tc⁢sc/2⁢(r+1)=1.875⁢Tc⁢scitalic-ϵ50subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐2𝑟11.875subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑠𝑐italic-epsilon RELOP:equals NUMBER:50 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.875 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon=50\,T_{c}\,s_{c}/2(r+1)=1.875\,T_{c}\,s_{c}. This value is close to the softest point of the equation of state, i.e., where the above mentioned effects on the lifetime are most drastic. In this representation, the rather long lifetime of matter with temperature T=Tc𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{c} (tl⁢i⁢f⁢e≃R/|vs⁢h|≃43⁢Rsimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑡𝑙𝑖𝑓𝑒𝑅subscript𝑣𝑠ℎsimilar-to-or-equals43𝑅italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-i italic-f italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-R MULOP:divide VERTBAR:| italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:43 italic-Rt_{life}\simeq R/|v_{sh}|\simeq 43\,R) for a sharp first order phase transition can be seen in a particularly clear way. This temporal temperature profile changes smoothly with increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. The drastic effect on the lifetime of matter with T=Tc𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{c} and T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} observed in Fig. 8 is readily explained via Fig. 9 as follows. For Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 the temperature stays constant (and equal to Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c}) over a rather long period of time ∼43⁢Rsimilar-toabsent43𝑅RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:43 italic-R\sim 43\,R, due to the small velocity of the rarefaction shock which consumes mixed phase matter and consequently takes a long time to reach the center x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0, cf. Fig. 5 (a). After that, the temperature drops sharply, cf. also Fig. 5 (g).

For small finite Δ⁢T=0.01⁢TcΔ𝑇0.01subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.01\,T_{c}, however, the temperature is already slowly decreasing with time, cf. also Figs. 5 (b,e). This leads to a much shorter lifetime of matter with the particular temperature T=Tc𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{c}, although the system remains obviously rather hot, T≃Tcsimilar-to-or-equals𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT\simeq T_{c}, for a time span ∼37⁢Rsimilar-toabsent37𝑅RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:37 italic-R\sim 37\,R that is only slightly smaller than in the previous case. This also accounts for the long lifetime of matter with T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} as observed in Fig. 8 (b). After that time, the cooling is again rather drastic due to the rarefaction shock which has then reached the center x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0. For increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, the cooling of hot matter becomes faster, which explains why the lifetime of matter with T=0.9⁢Tc𝑇0.9subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} is eventually also appreciably reduced, cf. Fig. 8 (c).

One also notes that the lifetime of matter with T=0.7⁢Tc𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.7\,T_{c} is not much influenced when increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, in accord with our above observation in Fig. 8. On the other hand, matter with even lower temperatures may survive longer. In general, the more rapid cooling of matter with higher temperatures as well as the delayed cooling of matter with smaller temperatures is well explained by the increasing “stiffness” of the equation of state at higher energy densities and its “softening” at smaller energy densities for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, cf. Fig. 2 (b).

An important conclusion to be drawn from Figs. 8 and 9 is that for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T the maximum in the lifetime of matter with temperature around Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} vanishes and that, for Δ⁢T=0.1⁢TcΔ𝑇0.1subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, there is no longer any irregularity that can be traced to the rapid variation of thermodynamical quantities in the phase transition region. In fact, in that case the shapes of the lifetime curves resemble those for the expansion of an ideal gas, cf. Figs. 8 (c) and (d). However, the existence of a transition from hadronic to quark and gluon degrees of freedom, the softening of the equation of state induced by that transition, and the resulting delayed expansion causes the lifetimes to be larger by an overall factor ∼10similar-toabsent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\sim 10, cf. also Fig. 9. We will discuss possible implications for proposed quark–gluon–plasma signatures in the next section.

To understand the qualitative behaviour of the curves in Fig. 8 (d), it is sufficient to note that the integral is always dominated by contributions from the upper boundary. This time is (up to a factor c=1𝑐1italic-c RELOP:equals NUMBER:1c=1) identical to the initial “radius” R𝑅italic-RR of the system. With equations (17) and (18) one can thus relate R𝑅italic-RR to ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}, similar as in (16). One has, however, to consider that a single shock is not the hydrodynamically stable solution in thermodynamically anomalous matter [24]. The correct solution is a sequence of single shocks and simple compression waves and, as a consequence, the initial energy density of the system is no longer constant over its extension 2⁢R2𝑅NUMBER:2 italic-R2\,R. For our purpose of obtaining a simple estimate of R𝑅italic-RR as a function of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} we will neglect these details and use a linear interpolation in the respective region of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}–values. The resulting initial size R𝑅italic-RR of the system as a function of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} is shown in Fig. 11. With this R⁢(ϵ0)𝑅subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-R OPEN:( italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)R(\epsilon_{0}) we then convert the tl⁢i⁢f⁢e/Rsubscript𝑡𝑙𝑖𝑓𝑒𝑅italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-i italic-f italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-Rt_{life}/R–scale in Fig. 8. The results are depicted in Fig. 12 and are qualitatively similar to Fig. 10. The rapid decrease of R𝑅italic-RR above ϵ0≃ϵQsimilar-to-or-equalssubscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}\simeq\epsilon_{Q} for Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 and 0.01⁢Tc0.01subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.01 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.01\,T_{c} strongly enhances the maximum in the lifetime of matter with temperatures near Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} and even creates a maximum in the lifetime of matter with cooler temperature, cf. Figs. 12 (a,b). The maxima observed in Fig. 10 (c) are now also more pronounced, cf. Fig. 12 (c), while Fig. 12 (d) still exhibits minima as in the corresponding Fig. 10 (d). The one–dimensional shock model thus proves to be the most optimistic scenario for quark–gluon–plasma signatures that require the existence of a distinguished maximum in the lifetime of hot matter at the softest point of the equation of state, like the proposed enhanced emission of electromagnetic probes [15].

We conclude that the lifetime of matter with temperatures near Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} is rather sensitive to the choice of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T and decreases rapidly for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T for initial energy densities around the softest point of the equation of state. On the other hand, regions of lower temperature (T≤0.7⁢Tc𝑇0.7subscript𝑇𝑐italic-T RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT\leq 0.7\,T_{c}, cf. Fig. 9) are less sensitive to variations in Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T and even survive longer with increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. Both phenomena have been explained in terms of the change in the “stiffness” of the equation of state when varying Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. For a fixed initial system size (independent of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}), increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T eliminates the maxima in the lifetime near the softest point of the equation of state (see Fig. 8 (c)). On the other hand, if one accounts for the Lorentz contraction of the initial size of the system, then such maxima in the lifetime persist even for finite Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. This is in contrast to the case without a phase transition, where the lifetimes rather exhibit minima for the corresponding values of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} (Figs. 10, 12 (d)). The lifetimes are also much longer (a factor of ∼10similar-toabsent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\sim 10) in case a rapid change in the degrees of freedom occurs. Experimental implications will be discussed in the next section.

5 Summary and Conclusions

In this work we have studied the one–dimensional hydrodynamic expansion of a finite system with an equation of state featuring a transition between (baryon-free) hadronic matter (with 3 massless degrees of freedom) and a quark–gluon plasma (with 37 massless degrees of freedom). The system’s evolution was studied as a function of its initial energy density ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} (which was assumed to be homogeneous) and the width Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T of the phase transition region in the equation of state. For Δ⁢T<Δ⁢T*Δ𝑇Δsuperscript𝑇Delta italic-T RELOP:less-than Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T<\Delta T^{*}, where Δ⁢T*≃0.07676⁢Tcsimilar-to-or-equalsΔsuperscript𝑇0.07676subscript𝑇𝑐Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.07676 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T^{*}\simeq 0.07676\,T_{c}, the equation of state has regions where matter becomes thermodynamically anomalous. Thus, rarefaction shock waves appear in the one–dimensional expansion, in contrast to the case Δ⁢T≥Δ⁢T*Δ𝑇Δsuperscript𝑇Delta italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T\geq\Delta T^{*}, where matter is thermodynamically normal for all energy densities and (overlapping) simple waves form the hydrodynamically stable expansion solution.

Temperature profiles are not very sensitive to Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T for initial energy densities well above and below the softest point of the equation of state, in agreement with the results of [11]. Variations of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T have, however, an appreciable influence on the temperature profiles for ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} near the softest point. In particular, rarefaction shocks are much weaker for finite Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T than in the case Δ⁢T=0Δ𝑇0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 and transform into “bumps” resembling smeared shocks in the thermodynamically normal case Δ⁢T≥Δ⁢T*Δ𝑇Δsuperscript𝑇Delta italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T\geq\Delta T^{*}. The shock strength is much smaller because, as shown via eq. (10), the region where matter is thermodynamically anomalous shrinks abruptly when Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T becomes finite. The “bump” structures in the thermodynamically normal case appear due to the variation of the velocity of sound in the transition region. In general, the equation of state at high energy densities becomes increasingly stiffer for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, which leads to more rapid expansion and cooling of the hot parts of the system. On the other hand, it becomes softer at smaller energy densities and thus the cooler parts of the system expand less rapidly and keep their temperature longer.

The above results were obtained assuming one–dimensional geometry and neglecting the finite (net) baryon density in the stopping regime. Nevertheless, we consider possible experimental consequences that may apply also in more realistic situations. The most important consequence from the experimental point of view is that the lifetimes of matter with temperatures near Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} decrease rapidly with increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, if ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} is in the vicinity of the softest point of the equation of state. This will have an effect on the electromagnetic signature proposed in [15]. For instance, the rate (per unit volume) of direct thermal photons with energy E𝐸italic-EE emitted from quark–gluon matter (at rest) is given by [25]

E⁢d⁢Rγd3⁢k=5⁢α⁢αS18⁢π2⁢T2⁢e-E/T⁢ln⁡(2.912⁢Eg2⁢T+1).𝐸dsuperscript𝑅𝛾superscriptd3k5𝛼subscript𝛼𝑆18superscript𝜋2superscript𝑇2superscript𝑒𝐸𝑇2.912𝐸superscript𝑔2𝑇1italic-E FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start d italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end k ARG:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:5 italic-alpha italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:18 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-E MULOP:divide italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2.912 italic-E ARG:end ARG:start italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-T ARG:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) PERIOD:.E\frac{{\rm d}R^{\gamma}}{{\rm d}^{3}{\rm k}}=\frac{5\alpha\alpha_{S}}{18\pi^{% 2}}~{}T^{2}e^{-E/T}\ln\left(\frac{2.912E}{g^{2}T}+1\right)~{}. (20)

For a fixed photon energy of E=1𝐸1italic-E RELOP:equals NUMBER:1E=1 GeV, a reduction of the temperature by ∼10-20%similar-toabsent10percent20RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:20 POSTFIX:percent\sim 10-20\%, as seen in Fig. 9 when Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T increases from 00NUMBER:0 to 0.1⁢Tc0.1subscript𝑇𝑐NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.1\,T_{c}, would reduce the number of photons by a factor of ∼2-4similar-toabsent24RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4\sim 2-4 (for Tc=170subscript𝑇𝑐170italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:170T_{c}=170 MeV, αS=0.4subscript𝛼𝑆0.4italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.4\alpha_{S}=0.4). In addition, the rate integrated over space–time will be smaller by an even larger factor, because the space–time volume of hot matter also shrinks for increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, cf. Figs. 3 – 7 (g,h,i). This makes a direct thermal electromagnetic signal of the quark–gluon plasma much more difficult to disentangle from background sources. On the other hand, after taking into account the expected Lorentz contraction of the initial size of the system, all lifetimes assume a maximum as a function of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} at the softest point of the equation of state, cf. Figs. 11, 12, independent of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T. The detection of this feature is, however, complicated by the broadening of this maximum with increasing Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T.

The generic feature that remains independent of Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T is that the lifetimes of matter of any temperature are larger by a factor of ∼10similar-toabsent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\sim 10 as compared to the ideal gas case. In this respect, the interferometric signal of such long lifetimes associated with a phase transition to the quark–gluon plasma [17] appears to be less sensitive to Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T than hard electromagnetic probes.

Finally we comment on the signature proposed in Ref. [16], where it was shown that the excitation function of the directed transverse flow has a minimum generated by the softest point of the equation of state, or in other words, the minimum in the function p/ϵ𝑝italic-ϵitalic-p MULOP:divide italic-epsilonp/\epsilon. Such a minimum still exists even for finite Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T, cf. Fig. 2 (b). However, the intrinsic dynamical mechanism for the decrease of the transverse directed flow was the inertness of the mixed phase that prevented it to expand and deflect spectator matter. This inertness is weakened at finite Δ⁢TΔ𝑇Delta italic-T\Delta T and hot matter in the phase transition region expands and cools much more rapidly than in the case of a strong first order phase transition, although still much slower than if there were no transition at all, cf. Figs. 8 (c) and (d). Further and more detailed, three–dimensional studies [26] are required before a definite conclusion of the effect on the transverse directed flow can be drawn.
